properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected Friday morning. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: east and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning. Remarks: A prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build on Boxing Day. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near high tide Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T02:00:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0633444205.2019
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: near 10 cm through tonight, Boxing Day and Boxing Day night. Maximum wind gusts: generally northwesterly 80 km/h, except locally 100 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day night. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula. Remarks: Scattered flurries or freezing drizzle will continue tonight and reintensify into snow on Boxing Day afternoon. Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 80 and 100 km/h will persist through tonight and Boxing Day and will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially in exposed areas. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:57:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T01:58:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1983663985.2019
Area: Bonavista Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain or freezing drizzle on tap Friday... Periods of rain or freezing drizzle are expected over Southwestern Quebec. Precipitations should begin overnight Thursday over the Ottawa Valley, Greater Montréal and the Montérégie Area before reaching Central Quebec during the day Friday. Amounts of freezing precipitation expected are not significant but should be enough to make roads and sidewalks icy and slippery. Consider the possibility of getting a head start or delay non-essential travels. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T07:36:28-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected to persist until this evening. The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 55. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T04:59:33-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing drizzle expected tonight and possibly into Thursday. Areas of freezing drizzle are affecting the region however the precipitation is light. Dense fog patches are also possible in some areas. Travel may be affected due to icy roads and reduced visibilities at times. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected tonight. Blizzard conditions will end early Thursday morning as the winds ease and the snow ends. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is occurring. Dense fog is expected to persist until midday Thursday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain or freezing drizzle are expected over Southwestern Quebec. They will begin Thursday in late afternoon over Témiscamingue and will then reach the Ottawa Valley, the Lower Laurentians, the Greater Montreal and the Montérégie area overnight Thursday. Precipitation is expected to taper to showers late Friday morning. The amount of freezing precipitation expected is not significant but will be enough to make surfaces, such as roads and sidewalks, icy and slippery. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T19:46:33-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Some freezing rain and freezing drizzle likely Thursday. Precipitation associated with a low pressure system will affect much of northeastern and central Ontario Thursday. Occasional freezing rain and freezing drizzle are likely, although amounts are not expected to be overly significant. Travel may be impacted as untreated surfaces may become slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: near 70 km/h from the northwest. Locations: Areas of the Trans Labrador highway near Cartwright Junction. Time span: Early Thursday morning until Thursday evening. Remarks: Coastal areas as well as the remainder of the Eagle River portion of the Trans Labrador highway can expect roughly 2 to 5 cm of snow on Boxing Day. The public is advised to plan any travel in the above mentioned areas accordingly. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:56:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T01:57:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3026680090.2019
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: near 70 km/h from the northwest. Locations: Makkovik and vicinity. Time span: continuing until Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Areas most likely to experience poor visibility in snow and blowing snow will be confined to the exposed coastline near Makkovik. Snowfall totals in the Postville area should be roughly 2 to 4 cm. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:55:48-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A frontal system pushing eastward across the northern Gulf of Alaska today will spread significant snow to the Haines Road and South Klondike Highway tonight through Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected with the highest accumulations occurring tonight. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of fine particulates are expected and will result in poor air quality. The high concentrations of pollutants are expected to diminish overnight tonight. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-26T11:59:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2019-12-26T03:47:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2616376680.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day morning. Remarks: Freezing drizzle will continue throughout the night and change back to snow Thursday morning. The freezing drizzle may mix at times with light snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains have eased. However, blizzard conditions will redevelop on Thursday morning and persist until Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T15:13:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-25T23:14:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0279902263.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring over some areas. Fog patches over some parts of the region are causing reduced visibility. There have been a few reports of visibility less than 200 metres. Travel may be hazardous tonight in areas of near zero visibility. Dense fog may persist into the middle of Thursday morning. ### Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T12:10:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T03:14:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3165145069.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: 10 to 15 cm through tonight, Boxing Day, and Boxing Day night. Maximum wind gusts: generally northwesterly 70 km/h, except locally 90 km/h along the coast. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day night. Locations: Gander and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Periods of light snow and freezing drizzle will continue tonight and then reintensify into snow, heavy at times, near noon on Boxing Day. Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 70 and 90 km/h will persist through tonight and Boxing Day and will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially in exposed areas. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:57:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T01:58:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2244155955.2019
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain likely Thursday night. A low pressure system will send precipitation towards the region Thursday evening or overnight into Friday. A period of freezing rain may develop that could warrant freezing rain warnings. Travel may be impacted in the Thursday evening to Friday morning time period as untreated surfaces may become slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-26T19:36:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T03:37:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1697520952.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm through tonight, Boxing Day, and Boxing Day night. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Time span: continuing until Boxing Day night. Locations: Clarenville and Terra Nova. Remarks: Scattered flurries will continue tonight and reintensify into snow near noon on Boxing Day. Strong northwesterly winds gusting between 70 and 80 km/h will persist through tonight and Boxing Day and will combine with the fresh snowfall to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow, especially in exposed areas. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:58:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T01:59:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2060666982.2019
Area: Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of snow, blowing snow, and strong northwesterly winds expected Boxing Day evening. In addition, very large waves, pounding surf, and elevated sea water levels are expected Friday morning. Snowfall Amounts: 5 to 10 cm Thursday afternoon and evening. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore Friday morning. Locations: northern Avalon Peninsula. Remarks: A brief period of snow and strong northwesterly winds gusting to 90 km/h will develop Boxing Day afternoon and persist into the evening. The fresh snow and strong winds may cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow over some areas late in the day on Boxing Day. In addition, a prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build on Boxing Day and Boxing Day night. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near the high tide Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-26T17:59:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-26T02:00:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3063302943.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada
